title: I wish to start watching LoL esports, but I am not sure where to begin.
body: This Saturday there is a game between SK Telecom T1 and GE Tigers, and Sunday there is a game between TIP and TSM. Would these games be good starting points?

replies.body:
Those would be pretty good starting points.

Saturday has H2K (best team EU) vs Fnatic.
c9 vs TL is the other Saturday match.

Sunday is the TSM vs TiP and SK vs UoL

Remember a lot of the older matches are on the [VODs](http://na.lolesports.com/vods/) page of Lol Esports (make sure you leave "Show Results" OFF for No Spoilers)

> [{quoted}](name=Vixanys,realm=NA,application-id=9hBQwnEU,discussion-id=MwE8gNzi,comment-id=0002,timestamp=2015-04-08T17:42:31.171+0000)
>
> Those would be pretty good starting points.
> 
> Saturday has H2K (best team EU) vs Fnatic.
> c9 vs TL is the other Saturday match.
> 
> Sunday is the TSM vs TiP and SK vs UoL
> 
> Remember a lot of the older matches are on the [VODs](http://na.lolesports.com/vods/) page of Lol Esports (make sure you leave "Show Results" OFF for No Spoilers)

H2K is the 3rd best EU team...

SK is 1 dimensional at best (and lacks warding ability that would prevent them from being shut down)

Fnatic is arguable the 1st or 2nd best team in EU, but I think h2K on pure skill, team coordination, team synergy and  objective control is at least in my opinion, what makes them the best team in EU.

> [{quoted}](name=Vixanys,realm=NA,application-id=9hBQwnEU,discussion-id=MwE8gNzi,comment-id=000200010000,timestamp=2015-04-10T14:14:56.429+0000)
>
> SK is 1 dimensional at best (and lacks warding ability that would prevent them from being shut down)
> 
> Fnatic is arguable the 1st or 2nd best team in EU, but I think h2K on pure skill, team coordination, team synergy and  objective control is at least in my opinion, what makes them the best team in EU.

FNC is without a doubt, better than H2K. They proved it both during regular season by beating them twice and in the semi finals were they won 3-2. We will soon know whether H2K is better than SK on the 3rd place best of 5 matches.
Thanks for the link man! I will watch some of those!

[I made a thread about this concept not too long ago...
](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/esports/OPs0EuVK-if-you-are-a-complete-noob-to-lcs-action-and-want-to-get-involved)

Basically if your completely new to Esports...

1. Find a team you care about.  If you don't have a preference stay with the "honorable favorites"... that is Fnatic for EU and TSM for NA.
2.  Watch *every* game the team played this split... even the "boring" ones.  You need to learn everyone so you have appreciation for the game.
3.  Watch all of the Prime Time Leagues for S5.  Watch this show each week... they do a good work summarizing LCS action.

Once you have done this and you have lots of time left over; you can start to watch other teams, or watch both EU/NA.  Also try to watch some of the matches of the "lesser" teams as well.  Once you do you will better understand and appreciate LCS.

If you want just good league games (with commentary) heres a few great ones:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XUFmbdTksuo#t=3m20s

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nRAoZJolrYI#t=4m11s

I watched the first but not the second

I'd say though the best game this season is either

UOL vs TSM game 1 San Jose (dat TF jungle),

UOL vs FNC Week 8 (its like a reverse xpeke if you know what that is) 

UOL vs GMB Game 2 playoffs (Man-bear-pig-flash-slap-first-blood)
The second one is my favorite game ever played, if you watch the first 5~10 minutes you'll understand. but I'll probably watch the ones you posted.
Uol watch all uol games they r fucking epic be sure to watch uol

The best way to get started is to just start. Yes, definitely watch those matches if you have the time. They're coming late in the competitive season, so you may not understand everything that's going on (TiP v TSM is a semi-final match, for example), but you'll never get invested if you don't start somewhere.

Also, I have no idea what's going on in Korea but I watch all the games I can from the scene because Monty and Doa are fucking hilarious and at the same time give more intelligent analysis than anything you'll ever hear out of the NA guys.
I agree.  The casters do a good job.  Expect to be lost at first, but you'll catch on.  The game play is entertaining at a minimum and you absorb more and more as time passes.

I would recommend starting with NA or EU. Korea and China frequently have better play... but their English casters are really lacking in energy or humour and the players have a bit less personality... and if you're just starting out it's probably better to watch the regions with the best casters.

I would personally recommend starting in LCS, the biggest reason being it isn't showing in the wee hours of the morning. Both NA and EU LCS are in the semifinals of the Spring Split playoffs, which basically means the first half of the season is ending and at the end of it there will be an NA and EU champion on top. 

TSM vs TiP should be a pretty good match. They are each fighting to get into the finals in a best of 5 match. TSM is usually pretty fun to watch, and its likely TiP is riding high after their dominating victory over Gravity in the quarter finals. 

Not to discourage you from watching LPL or LCK (Chinese and Korean leagues respectively), I just know most people don't want to be up at 4:00 in the morning just to watch a League match. NA LCS is usually at noon PST on Saturdays and Sundays, EU LCS is on Thursday Friday and starts at...9am PST? This week is unusual because of playoffs.

Ask me questions if you have any! :)
Well I would be watching them later in the day in the VOD section. I am mostly interested in LCS, but I have seen a few games with Faker, and he is always entertaining to watch.

If you want to follow SKT then go for it! I just don't personally have as much knowledge on the LCK broadcast.

I can tell you that the LCS coverage is quite good though. :)
LCK has some of the best commentators in the world of League Esports. ggDoA and ggCMontecristo! Super Powers of Class and Sophistication.

I'm sorry to say this but....I don't like Montecristo

*gasp!*

Yeah sorry, I've never been a fan of Montecristo. That's just my personal opinion though.

As far as shoutcasters go, I miss Joe "Just call me Joe" Miller and Deman for EU LCS. Deficio is good, the new guy is fine and Quickshot is ok, but EU just doesn't have "it" anymore for me. I was happy to see Joe at IEM though.

Joe Miller is my favorite, but Monte and Riv are the only other ones I like. Jatt is usually just wrong and it bugs me. Deficio, and this may sound bad, I hate his accent. I just do. Quickshot, Sjokz and Pyro just don't do it for me. I can't even count Phreak (he's become annoying) and Zirene/Dash are ok...i guess.

I guess most of the above is just personality. While I like correct and factual information. Which is what Monte brings in this Lack of Joe Miller world.

I think the Coaches in EU are the funniest

The Gambit coach said that the UOL is gonna bull some BS like "Frozen Heart first item Varus Top"

Dem Na coaches are too salty (cuz Na is the atomic symbol for sodium :)
thanks for pointing that out.  I didnt bring my reading glasses and almost didnt see what you did there.
I live in a cave and I saw what he did there. It was cheesy.
VODs man VODs! You don't need to watch things live to still excited!

Oh phooey, watching live is where it's at. :P

I'm just more familiar with NA and EU, so while I'm sure there are exciting games in the east, I can't really say much about other than what info I randomly pick up from events like IEM.
Neither, watch tsm vs gravity

I actually consider myself still fairly new to the LCS scene. I caught a few games here and there at Worlds but I didn't follow much before that. I knew most of the teams names though, couldn't go anywhere in League without seeing TSM, C9, LMQ(when they were still around), CLG, Fnatic. Worlds was probably the best time for anyone to get into LCS. Plenty of teams to choose for your favorites. That was where I officially became a C9 fan. But you probably don't want to wait for This year's Worlds. I'd say watch a few VODs of previous matches first to get a general feel for it(and to pick a team to root for if you want), Learn who the casters and analysts are. But if your deadset on getting into the matches this weekend, then I'd recommend either TSM vs TIP or TL vs C9. TSM is currently the #1 in NA and that's got to boost their confidence going into this match. TIP though is really strong right now and will put up a good fight. TL is finally looking strong with Piglet, the ADC who won Worlds a few years back, on their side. C9 had a rough start to the season but after taking down both TSM and CLG to secure 2nd place, their looking really strong. Hell, C9 were the defending champs for a long time until TSM beat them 3-2 in last years summer playoffs. It's your choice ultimately so do whatever you want. Welcome to the world of LoL eSports.

My Breaking Bad man, Although watching the games will be entertaining, I would suggest, if you have time, to catch up on all the games for NA LCS since 2 weeks ago. You would have more clue as to what is on the plate etc.

It's like watching "Better Call Saul" is good, but it would be better if you watched "Breaking Bad" first.

That's a lot of VODs though. Even the shortest games are still 30 minutes if you include watching champ select and getting into the game. What about some of the longer ones? 

This is probably a good time to get into it, since playoffs is a ton of fun with awesome picks. Plus you can get hyped for Summer split, which can be a fresh start for a new viewer.
Well I read up on the current rankings and recent game results, so I have a decent understanding of who ranks where.
